docs.text: this is the best british gangster film since the long good friday .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: jon bennet ( played by andrew howard ) is an extremely good assassin .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: as such he is probably an evil man but it does not worry him .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he has become an unquestioning weapon .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is in the employ of a kingpin ( david calder ) far more evil than he is .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but even assassins have innocent pasts .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he runs into an old from school days and he is married to a mutual girl friend from school .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: complicating matters is that they live near where he had a recent job and their young daughter may have seen him at the crime .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a big piece of what makes this film work is the depiction of the kingpin .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: calder is a familiar actor in britain , though not frequently seen in the us .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he was seen in the world is not enough .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: here he creates one of the best screen villains in recent years .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is at once seductive and repellent like a beautiful venomous snake .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his lair is underground , apparently in a sewer , where he lives like the king of sewer rats .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is the kingpin who pulls the strings that will control bennet's life .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: paul sarossy who directs spent most of his career as a cinematographer and like the kingpin's lair , he has molded images of class and style out of the darkness .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: by using semi-darkness and letting the colors of deep blue and black dominate every scene he makes the film visually as ominous as anything in this nether world .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is a world that is cold and unfriendly .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: sorossy creates a world of violence much more by what we hear than what we see .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is a film with a great deal of physical violence occurring just out of reach .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: we see very little but we hear a great deal more and we imagine more than that .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the screenplay is by peter waddington based on the novel by neil cross , but it is sarossy's film all the way .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it creates indelible images of evil .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i rate it an 8 on the 0 to 10 scale and a low +3 on the -4 to +4 scale .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: ( i do hope they do not use the tagline " don't mess with mr . in-between . " )
docs.label: positive
